'''David Lee Murphy''' (born January 7, 1959) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. He is best known for his #1 country hits "[[Dust on the Bottle]]" and "[[Everything's Gonna Be Alright (David Lee Murphy and Kenny Chesney song)|Everything's Gonna Be Alright]]", as well as the hit songs "[[Party Crowd]]", "[[Out with a Bang (song)|Out with a Bang]]", "[[Every Time I Get Around You]]", "[[The Road You Leave Behind]]", and "[[Loco (David Lee Murphy song)|Loco]]". He has released five solo studio albums: ''[[Out with a Bang]]'' (1994), ''[[Gettin' Out the Good Stuff]]'' (1996), ''[[We Can't All Be Angels]]'' (1997), ''[[Tryin' to Get There]]'' (2004), and ''[[No Zip Code]]'' (2018). His songs "Just Once" and "We Can't All Be Angels" appeared on the [[soundtrack]]s of the films ''[[8 Seconds]]'' (1994) and ''[[Black Dog (1998 film)|Black Dog]]'' (1998), respectively.

Murphy took a hiatus from recording in 2004, and has co-written several singles for other artists, including the hits "[[Living in Fast Forward]]" for [[Kenny Chesney]], "[[Anywhere With You]]" for [[Jake Owen]], "[[Big Green Tractor]]" for [[Jason Aldean]], and "[[Are You Gonna Kiss Me or Not]]" for [[Thompson Square]]. On April 6, 2018, Murphy and [[Kenny Chesney]] released a studio album together, ''No Zip Code'', which features their hit song "[[Everything's Gonna Be Alright (David Lee Murphy and Kenny Chesney song)|Everything's Gonna Be Alright]]".

==Biography==
Murphy was born in [[Herrin, Illinois]], the son of Jessie (West) and Dr. Jack Murphy. His father died from a heart attack on December 17, 1982, when Murphy was 23.<ref>[https://thesouthern.com/news/local/obituaries/jessie-l-west-murphy-kibler/article_0633c812-08f0-5195-8c36-ac04dc8b6c95.html Obituary of Jessie L. (West) Murphy Kibler] thesouthern.com</ref><ref name="allmusic"/> By 1983, he had moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], seeking a successful career in country music. Two years later, he was spotted by record producer [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]] at a club in Nashville, although Brown did not sign Murphy to a record deal until nearly a decade later.<ref name="cmt1">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/murphy_david_lee/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040110163422/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/murphy_david_lee/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 10, 2004 |title=David Lee Murphy: Biography |access-date=2007-11-10 |work=CMT.com}}</ref> In the meantime, however, Murphy did co-write album cuts for [[Reba McEntire]] and [[Doug Stone]].<ref name="cmt1"/>

==Musical career==
Murphy's first recording for [[MCA Nashville]] was the song "Just Once", which was included on the [[8 Seconds (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] to the 1994 film ''[[8 Seconds]]''.<ref name="allmusic"/> In 1994, "Just Once" entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart, reaching #36. The same year, Murphy began work on his debut album ''[[Out with a Bang]]'', released in early 1995. The album produced three hit singles overall, including "Party Crowd," which became the most-played country song of 1995, as well as "[[Dust on the Bottle]]", a #1 single.<ref name="allmusic"/> ''Out with a Bang'' became the best-selling album for a new male country act in 1995 and was certified gold by the [[RIAA]].<ref name="allmusic"/>

''[[Gettin' Out the Good Stuff]]'' was the title of Murphy's second album, released in 1996. It produced back-to-back Top 5 singles in "Every Time I Get Around You" and "The Road You Leave Behind".<ref name="allmusic"/><ref name="oldies">{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/David-Lee-Murphy.html |title=David Lee Murphy biography |access-date=2007-11-10 |work=Oldies.com}}</ref> "Every Time I Get Around You" hit #2 on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks in Canada and was named that publication's top song for 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?brws_s=1&file_num=nlc008388.9734&volume=64&issue=18&issue_dt=December%2016%201996&type=1&interval=24&PHPSESSID=kf6e901abaiav6kf0lhl7u7ub7 |title=Top 100 Country Tracks |access-date=2008-09-13 |date=1996-12-16 |work=RPM }}{{dead link|date=January 2020|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>

Murphy's third and final album for MCA, titled ''[[We Can't All Be Angels]]'', was released in 1997.<ref name="kimmy">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1473190/20030623/murphy_david_lee.jhtml |title=David Lee Murphy - Just for Kicks |access-date=2007-11-10 |last=Wix |first=Kimmy |date=1997-11-24 |work=CMT.com}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> In a 1997 interview, Murphy revealed that he had intended for this album to be experimental in nature, saying that he "wanted to create just a whole different tone, sonically. I just wanted a different sounding record."<ref name="kimmy"/> ''We Can't All Be Angels'' had two singles, "All Lit up in Love" and "Just Don't Wait Around 'Til She's Leavin'", peaking at #25 and #37 on the country chart.<ref name="allmusic"/><ref name="oldies"/>

===2000s===
{{main|List of songs written by David Lee Murphy}}
By the 2000s, Murphy had shifted his focus to songwriting. One of his first cuts in the 2000s was the title track to [[Aaron Tippin]]'s 2000 album ''[[People Like Us (Aaron Tippin album)|People Like Us]]''; this song was a Top 20 for Tippin in 2001. [[Trick Pony]] also entered the country Top 20 a year later with another one of Murphy's compositions — the title track to their 2002 album ''[[On a Mission (Trick Pony album)|On a Mission]]''.<ref name="cmt1"/> Murphy also co-wrote album cuts for several other artists, including [[Brooks & Dunn]], [[Montgomery Gentry]], and [[Hank Williams, Jr.]]<ref name="cmt1"/>

[[Koch Entertainment]] signed Murphy to his second recording contract in 2004. That year, he released his fourth studio album, ''[[Tryin' to Get There]]''. The album, whose title track was co-written by [[Waylon Jennings]] prior to his death in 2002,<ref name="loco">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1486208/20040406/murphy_david_lee.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070622183621/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1486208/20040406/murphy_david_lee.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 22, 2007 |title=David Lee Murphy Gets "Loco" With New Album |access-date=2007-11-10 |last=Gilbert |first=Calvin |date=2004-04-06 |work=CMT.com}}</ref> produced the Top Five hit "[[Loco (David Lee Murphy song)|Loco]]", which reached #5 in 2004. The only other single from ''Tryin' to Get There'' was "Inspiration", a collaboration with singer and guitarist [[Lee Roy Parnell]], which peaked at #48.

Following the closure of the Koch Nashville record label, Murphy continued working as a songwriter, scoring his first outside Number One with [[Kenny Chesney]]'s 2006 single "[[Living in Fast Forward]]". 2007 produced three more chart singles co-written by Murphy: [[Gary Allan]]'s "A Feelin' Like That" (co-written by Ira Dean, then a member of [[Trick Pony]]), [[Van Zant (band)|Van Zant]]'s "Goes Down Easy", and [[Blake Shelton]]'s "The More I Drink". 2008 saw the release of [[Keith Anderson]]'s "Somebody Needs a Hug" and the [[Eli Young Band]]'s "[[Always the Love Songs]]", two more songs co-written by Murphy, and [[Jason Aldean]] topped the country charts in September 2009 with "[[Big Green Tractor]]", which Murphy wrote with [[Jim Collins (singer)|Jim Collins]]. [[Josh Thompson (singer)|Josh Thompson]] charted in 2010 with "[[Way Out Here (song)|Way Out Here]]", another Murphy co-write.

Other Murphy co-writes include [[Thompson Square]]'s "[[Are You Gonna Kiss Me or Not]]" and "[[Everything I Shouldn't Be Thinking About]]", [[Kenny Chesney]]'s "[[Live a Little (song)|Live a Little]]", "[[Pirate Flag (song)|Pirate Flag]]", and "[[Cosmic Hallelujah#Track listing|Bar at the End of the World]]", Aldean's "[[The Only Way I Know]]", [[Jake Owen]]'s "[[Anywhere with You]]", [[Blackberry Smoke]]'s "Ain't Much Left of Me", and [[The Road Hammers]]' "Get On Down the Road".

In 2017, Murphy signed to Reviver Records and announced that he would release a new album, ''No Zip Code''. The album is produced by [[Kenny Chesney]] and [[Buddy Cannon]], Chesney's longtime producer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.countryschatter.com/2017/09/david-lee-murphy-signs-to-reviver-chesney-cannon-produce-no-zip-codes/|title=David Lee Murphy Signs To Reviver; Chesney-Cannon Produce NO ZIP CODES|website=Countryschatter.com|date=September 21, 2017}}</ref>

==Charitable efforts==
In 2000, Murphy hosted a series of concerts in his hometown of Herrin, Illinois, raising $25,000 for the Jack Murphy fund, which David Lee started in honor of his father, Dr. Jack Murphy, a local civic leader and educator.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1476791/20030813/murphy_david_lee.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070622034029/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1476791/20030813/murphy_david_lee.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 22, 2007 |title=Murphy Performs for Charity |access-date=2007-11-10 |date=2000-03-10 |work=CMT.com}}</ref>
